oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Jimmie Dickens Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Jimmie Dickens (performer). Interview conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Jimmie Dickens; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) 'Little' Jimmie Dickens and Biff Collie start by talking segregationists and the Grand Ole Opry -- (03:04) Dickens compares his own show compared to Opry experience -- (03:21) Collie describes first impressions of Dickens on the Opry -- (04:50) Dickens radio spots and excerpts -- (06:52) Dickens tells is background information until Collie interrupts with comedic relief -- (07:32) Dickens continues to list off family members -- (08:10) Dickens talks about father and family working as a miners -- (8:59) Dickens recalls going to the store and food cooked by his grandparents -- (10:03) Dickens begins to discuss the musical influences in his home -- (11:58) Dickens first performance at a talent show is discussed -- (13:41) Collie and Dickens talk about Dickens height (4'11") and being in a group -- (14:59) Dickens talks about selling Grit newspapers -- (16:08) Dickens talks about retaking semesters in high school -- (16:56) Dickens talks about Roy Acuff and singing in Indianapolis -- (19:56) Dickens talks about meeting Roy Acuff and joining the Opry -- (21:13) Dickens talks about first impressions of Nashville when he pulled up with his house trailer -- (22:03) Dicken's first experience with the Ryman Auditorium and staying with Acuff -- (23:53) Dickens speaks of starting his first band after more than a year in Nashville -- (24:30) Dickens talks about being branded a novelty singer -- (26:42) Dickens talks about his original manager -- (28:18) Dickens speaks of magnetism and drawing crowds -- (29:27) 'Take an Old Cold Tater and Wait' and other successful Dickens records are discussed -- (30:34) Dickens recording with Johnny Carson is described as instantaneous -- (31:19) "Straight-Up" recording is discussed -- (31:38) "Sleeping at the Foot of a Bed" is talked about how it stems from a poem and Boudleaux Bryant's first song was wrote for Dickens -- (33:28) Dickens novelty songs are discussed -- (34:00) Dickens speaks on Acuff's sincerity -- (34:58) Dickens answers "What kind of person is Minnie Pearl?" -- (35:55) Dickens talks about Grandpa Jones growing stories and Ferlin Husky -- (38:24) Dickens unique wardrobe is discussed -- (40:06) Art Satherley's difficulty to work with is brought up -- (41:26) Collie talks about Bob Wills experience about talking during recording -- (42:09) Dickens talks about being on tour and discovering Marty Robins -- (43:42) Dickens and Collie talk about finally getting into the Country Music Hall of Fame -- (45:26) Dickens talks about how life has changed -- (46:06) The Camel Caravan group and Phillip Morris Caravan group are reminisce about -- (48:27) Collie and Dickens discuss how Dickens views new acts as well as Conway Twitty -- (49:20) Dickens talks about opening shows for Louise Mandrell -- (50:00) Dickens endorsement of Garth Brooks and Clint Black -- (50:54) Dickens gives Acuff his selection for greatest country influence with consideration to Ernest Tubb and Hank Williams -- (52:13) Dickens contemplates who he believes should be in the Country Music Hall of Fame® -- (53:01) Dickens puts his lens of what he defines as an entertainer -- (54:10) Dickens reflects on what he would like to be remembered for -- (54:44) Dickens talks about a roast and a host having issues -- (56:00) Dickens jokes about being a stand-up comic
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Dickens, Little Jimmy, 1920-2015; Collie, Biff;
